Triggering Event: He scrolled through Instagram, stopping at his old friend's post - a vibrant street art mural, tagged with 'Us'. They hadn't collaborated in years, but now it seemed everyone was talking about this piece. His wife glanced over, "That's amazing, isn't it?" He nodded, feeling the familiar pang of envy, not for the art, but for the attention it brought his friend.
Generated Assessment: Oh, I think my husband is just jealous because he has to work all day, while our friends get to paint murals like that. Maybe they're just more talented than him? Or maybe we don't know how hard it takes to create something so beautiful. That mural looks amazing! But honestly, I'm just glad people are talking about it. It makes me feel good that someone else is getting recognition for their art. My husband always says I have too much time on my hands, but now I can use it to appreciate these things. You know, instead of focusing on my own stuff. I might even try painting someday... who knows? I hope he gets the recognition he deserves for his talent, but I won't be surprised if everyone suddenly becomes an art critic. After all, it's not every day you see such a masterpiece. The way it brings us together reminds me of when we used to hang out in college. Those were special moments, weren't they? Even though my husband thinks I'm wasting time by doing this, I'll enjoy watching the world go by, one mural at a time.

Triggering Event: He returned home late, exhausted from another grueling shift at the restaurant. His wife was already asleep, but the kitchen table held a single plate with remnants of what must have been her dinner. A note beside it read, "I waited, but you were late again." He felt a pang in his chest as he realized she'd eaten alone once more, and guilt washed over him like the heat from his kitchen's stoves.
Generated Assessment: He came home to an empty house, the dinner plates still warm from the oven. My heart sank knowing she ate alone once more. She knew he'd be late, but why didn't she wait? Why did she eat while he was stuck on the road? Didn't she care about his exhaustion? The thought cut deep, and I couldn't help but wonder if she even cared about me anymore. Maybe she just wanted to get rid of the food before I arrived. That would explain the leftovers, wouldn't it? I feel like she doesn't love me; she just tolerates me because I'm her husband. It's hard to keep going when everything feels so lonely. I try to remind myself that maybe this is just how life goes for couples who work together, but it doesn't make it easier to accept. I wish I could just go back in time and tell myself things differently. Maybe then we wouldn't be here, struggling through our days. But no matter what I say, the truth remains - we're just two people trying to survive in a world that doesn't always treat us kindly.

Triggering Event: At the store's entrance, he notices her, a woman around his wife's age, laughing with the younger cashier. Their shared joke seems intimate, their body language familiar. He feels his stomach churn, doubt creeping in like an unwanted customer during closing time. Was it always like this? The laughter, the easy camaraderie? Or is he just now noticing because of that comment yesterday, "You're not getting any younger, are you?" His hands tremble slightly as he sorts the magazines, each rustle echoing his insecurity.
Generated Assessment: fuck my life why is she laughing with another man at the grocery store i was so happy to see her smile but now it makes me feel like shit and i dont know why im even thinking about it i just want to go home but i cant shake this feeling that im being replaced and maybe ive been replaced before too i remember how i used to be jealous of all the women who would flirt with my husband but now im the one who feels insecure and i dont know why i feel like im losing my mind

Triggering Event: While grading papers at his dining room table, he paused at a familiar handwriting and felt a pang of regret. It was little Jamie's, the boy who'd left school months ago, his family having moved suddenly for work. He remembered their last conversation, Jamie's excited chatter about his upcoming birthday party, which never happened. The empty space where Jamie's name should be on the class roster seemed to stare back at him, a stark reminder of opportunities missed and words unsaid.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, my mind is always telling me things are going to go wrong. Like, I'm just waiting for something bad to happen. And it does. It has. This guy's gone missing, we don't know if he's even alive, and there's no sign of him anywhere. I feel like this is just going to keep happening. There's always some kid getting hurt, someone dying, or some other tragedy. It's just how it is. I try to avoid thinking about it, but deep down, I know it's inevitable. Every time I see a new student, I think they'll get hurt, too. It feels like fate is setting them up for disaster. Even when I try to focus on the positive—like all these kids coming back from summer vacation—I still worry that something terrible is just around the corner. Maybe I'm just jinxed, but it feels like every possibility ends in tragedy. My life isn't so great either, but at least I have people to help me through it. What am I saying? Of course, everything is going to end badly. I can barely handle my own problems, let alone imagine anything good happening. I guess I'm just stuck in this cycle of expecting the worst, and it's exhausting. But hey, maybe I'm just living in a bubble, and what I think is bad actually turns out okay. Still, I wouldn’t bet on it.
